title: Tuesday, 22nd December, 2015

(Very believable fjp73)

PM

BE

BMO says "we were wrong about 2015. So here's where we might be wrong about 2016."

11:16 am
BE

The year 2015 was another difficult one for oil and gas investors. Brent crude oil prices fell by roughly 30%, which led to a similar decline in oil and gas equity values. In our ‘2015 Year Ahead’ report we laid out three plausible scenarios: (1) our base case, which forecast Brent crude oil prices of $50-60/bbl over the first half of 2015 and $60-80/bbl over the second half of the year; (2) a bull case, which forecast a Brent trading range of $85-95; and a bear case, which suggested a Brent trading range of $50-60/bbl. The actual trading range in 2015 proved to be even more ‘bearish’ than our bear case, with Brent generally trading between $36 and $60/bbl. So what did we get wrong? In our view the biggest mistake we (and the market) made was underestimating Iraqi production. In our 2015 outlook, we assumed that Iraq production would average 2.9 million bpd; actual production was roughly 1 million bpd higher. We also assumed that Saudi Arabia would be content to hold production at 9.2 million bpd whereas actual production was roughly 800,000 bpd higher. In our view, this incremental 1.8 million bpd of production was the principal reason that global oil inventories swelled by more than 340 million barrels to a record high of approximately 3.1 billion barrels and why crude oil prices have collapsed.

BE

As we consider the outlook for 2016, we again see three plausible scenarios: (1) a bull case wherein the ongoing civil war in Iraq and lack of re-investment leads to a collapse in production and/or the Saudi’s agree to rein in production as they did in 1999 in order to support higher prices. The anticipated trading range for Brent under this scenario is $55-70-plus/bbl; (2) a bear case where Iran is able to add 1 million bpd of production over the first half of 2016 while other OPEC members hold steady (or even more bearish Libya increases production) and U.S. producers are slow to reduce drilling activity, leading to the possibility that inventories threaten to reach capacity. The likely trading range for Brent under this case is $20-40/bbl. We consider each of these scenarios to be too speculative to be investable base cases. Since we don’t have any inside track on information from the House of Saud or the actual state of Iraqi and Libyan oil fields, we have to assume that Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Libya hold production relatively flat. We also assume that Iran ramps up at a moderate pace over the course of 2016, leaving the burden of rebalancing the oil market to non-OPEC producers and the U.S. in particular. We estimate that the global oil market is oversupplied by close to 1 million bpd. Balancing the global oil market requires that surplus be eliminated. The only reliable mechanism to accomplish this is the price of oil. Our base case is that crude oil prices remain weak long enough to convince U.S. producers to cut the rig count by a further 25-30% and hold it at that level for several quarters. This price level should also be low enough to shut-in some uneconomic production such as conventional heavy oil and mature offshore platforms. We believe that this should be enough to balance supply and demand by the end of 2016 and move the market into a supply deficit in 2017, which would result in inventories being drawn down to normal levels. This should result in a trading range for Brent of $35-55/bbl in 2016 and $50-60/bbl in 2017.

BE

Given this backdrop, we recommend that investors continue to remain on the sidelines over the first half of the year. Admittedly the main risk is that most investors are already underweight energy and inevitably there will be a stampede of short-covering and rush to increase exposure as oil prices inevitably recover; however, we believe that this risk is minimal over the first half of 2016 because the supply-demand balance is so far out of kilter. We would continue to avoid companies with high debt levels and dividends that are funded by debt, bearing in mind that these likely will be the companies that will get re-rated the quickest when oil prices recover.

11:27 am
BE

So Morgan Stanley likes Comcast but advises it to buy other stuff.

BE

What about wireless/M&A? We expect a light touch approach by Comcast during the upcoming incentive auction, and that spectrum purchases are more likely to be levered into stronger partnerships with wireless carriers than a step to either buy or build its way into a scale position. We estimate Comcast can spend up to ~$6B on the auction, buyback the $6B we have been estimating in '16E, and remain around 2x levered. We have no insights into the rumoured ITV acquisition, which the company has denied according to press reports. We would prefer Comcast allocate the ~$16-17B of capital that would be needed for ITV elsewhere, away from assets that derive the majority of its revenue from TV advertising.

PM

Sorry a bit late

11:28 am
BE

While Comcast has spoken about its interest in acquiring international media assets, the news, if true, comes as a surprise given that Liberty Global owns ~10% of ITV and increased its interest in the company just a few months ago, which could potentially set up a competitive situation for the asset. Also, investors are likely to struggle with the following:

Capital allocation choices will need patience: One of the biggest issues investors have struggled with in the case of Comcast is its capital structure allocation. Comcast has clearly shown a preference over the last few years for large transformative deals (Disney, TWC, NBCU). While the company has increased its capital returns meaningfully over the last decade as well (dividends and buybacks have grown at a 28.9% CAGR (2011-15E) to 112.5% of FCF in 2015E from 41.2% of FCF in 2011), the scale of the company's M&A ambitions have dwarfed its capital returns. An acquisition of ITV, however, would result in leverage moving up above Comcast’s comfort range of ~2x (specially with Universal Japan’s results being consolidated), which could have implications for capital returns going forward. In our opinion, this preference towards M&A appears to be well anchored in an expansive long-term vision about the state of the ecosystem. While it is tough to believe the company had the foresight to envision the present state of the ecosystem and its fragmentation, its vertically integrated structure has provided Comcast with more optionality than other media or cable companies.

BE

Also, in hindsight the company's vertical integration with NBCU, which happened in the same time period that Time Warner was splitting from Time Warner Cable, highlights the fact that strategically while its decisions at the time of their making tend to not have immediate benefits, Comcast's execution combined with access to optionality in an evolving ecosystem has led to more visibility around core cash flows as well as greater operating leverage. In that context, if the news about Comcast's interest in ITV is true, there is unlikely to be immediate revenue or cost synergies on a scale large enough near term, similar to the situation when Comcast acquired NBCU. Also, the company's overall revenue and EBITDA mix proforma for a potential ITV transaction does not change materially (37% content revenue pre-deal to 41% post deal; 25% content EBITDA pre-deal to 27.5% post deal). However, ITV, through its studio segment, holds important content rights like The Voice (one of the top-rated shows on NBC), Utopia, Hell’s Kitchen, Mr. Selfridge etc. ITV's content portfolio could be one of the key attractions for NBC along with a distribution platform on scale in the UK which can help the company monetize its own portfolio of content more effectively outside the US. On the back of its TV studio roll-up strategy as well as support from ad growth in the UK, ITV is expected to grow 14% this year.

Valuation: Unlike Comcast’s NBCU acquisition, ITV is trading at an all-time high valuation of 11.6x 2016E consensus EBITDA, a significant premium to Comcast, other media companies in the US as well as other Free to Air broadcasters in Europe such as RTL, Mediaset, MS Espana etc. While the strength of the US dollar does provide some offset, we are unclear as to why this is an asset worth owning at this point of the valuation cycle, especially when there is some likelihood of competitive bidding or a steep ask from Liberty Global.

Overall, if the news is true, it is tough for us to see this being perceived positively by investors given the lack of visibility on potential upside from this source. Also, recent comments from the company increase the likelihood of a downward drift in consensus numbers for 2016 (higher capex, higher programming costs, higher D&A, tough comps in studios, offset partly by higher-than-expected retrans and potentially positive video net adds). Therefore, the stock may see some incremental volatility.

BE

Oh, and since we're here, Shore pushing an ITV buy call.

11:29 am
BE

Although not a central plank of our positive investment case on the company’s stock, we have often expressed our belief that the presence of serial telecom media consolidator Liberty Global is a validation of its strategic value. Specifically, we believe the group’s burgeoning international content exposure (SCF 27% of FY2015F revenue), cash generative characteristics (102% three year ave. conversion from op. profit), and ability to deliver and unrivalled mass market audience to UK advertisers make it an attractive target.

In addition to these positives we expect another bullish update at the time of the group’s prelims on 2 March (helped by reportedly strong demand for TV advertising over the pre-Christmas period) and forecast attractive aggregate EPS and DPS growth of 43% and 76% respectively over out three year forecast horizon, with organic progress likely to be enhanced by further acquisitions in the content space. We also regard further special dividend payments as a real possibility during FY2016F, FY2017F or both. Against this backdrop we continue to view the group’s valuation (15.7x 11.8x FY2016F P/E and DY ratios respectively, 2.5% yield) as undemanding despite a period of positive share price performance and maintain our BUY recommendation.

Fastjet PLC (FJET:LSE): Last: 43.80, down 3.32 (-7.06%), High: 43.80, Low: 43.67, Volume: 351.23k
PM

Fastjet has warned of weaker than expected revenue for 2015E and 2016E. The recent election in Tanzania has resulted in a prolonged period of subdued government and civil service traffic, with a wider dampening effect on flying activity. In response, management has slowed the group's capacity growth. We have made sharp cuts to our forecasts, but management still expects the group to be cash generative in 2016E. We do not believe the short-term challenges alter the long-term opportunity in African aviation, nor the validity of Fastjet's low cost model. Our target price is cut to 90p from 230p, but our recommendation remains BUY.

Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 87.90, up 1.3 (+1.50%), High: 89.00, Low: 87.45, Volume: 238.32k

11:49 am
BE

Buying in some more exploration.

BE

Stifel can talk us through it, even though it can't find much enthusiasm.

BE

While we see the acquisition of additional exploration as largely neutral and not changing anything in our current valuation, we would not be surprised if, at present, the market is not too keen on deep water exploration spending. Besides the $16.9m cash to be paid by Ophir, it appears the block has a well commitment in the next two years. Assuming $50m gross cost of the well, it appears Ophir will spend an additional c$30m (~60% of the well cost) in the next two years. Interestingly, assuming $50m well costs, $16.9m upfront cash payment and 10% cost carry, would essentially imply approximately 2-1 promote on this transaction.

11:51 am
BE

This is Cote d'ivoire, block CI-513

BE

Ophir will pay $16.9m (for past costs) for 45% interest in the block and it will become operator.

In addition, Ophir will contribute an additional 10% (over and above its participating interest share) towards the drilling of the first exploration well to be drilled on the block.

The new PSC incorporates adjustments to fiscal terms and holding costs agreed with the Government of Côte d'Ivoire that reflect the current commodity price, but this has also resulted in an extension to the previous minimum work commitments on the block and now requires that an exploration well be drilled within two years of the signing of this new PSC.

BE

So, meh.

PM

Tata Steel UK Limited (TSUK), an indirect subsidiary company of Tata Steel Europe (TSE), today announced the signing of a Letter of Intent with Greybull Capital to enter exclusive negotiations for the potential sale of its Long Products Europe business.

The memorandum covers several UK-based assets including TSUK's Scunthorpe steelworks, mills in Teesside and northern France, an engineering workshop in Workington, a design consultancy in York, and associated distribution facilities. It also includes Scottish mills in Dalzell and Clydebridge which are currently being mothballed.

PM

Greybull Capital LLP is a family office that makes long term investments in private companies. We have a broad portfolio spanning investments in the energy, technology, retail, industrial and manufacturing sectors in both Europe and the United States.

Greybull focuses on backing management teams with opportunities in early stage, growth, and mature companies. Through investment and innovation Greybull aims to help create growing and profitable enterprises.
